awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Can artificial intelligence (AI) invent? And if so, so what?
awd_abstract_narration:
Sustained economic development depends upon the intensity and productivity of efforts devoted to inventive activity. There is a growing concern that the productivity of human inventive activity (as measured by the number of patent applications per patent author) is declining, and that this decline may reflect the growing volume and complexity of technical knowledge and the increasing effort needed to identify intellectual novelty. Computer scientists and proponents of Artificial Intelligence (AI) suggest that, because of AI’s ability to execute combinatorial search effectively and rapidly, AI might be helpful in the search for new inventions. This proposition begets two research questions: can AI invent and, if so, will AI invention augment or displace human inventors? The project examines the current and potential inventive capabilities of AI by tapping into insights accumulated from the study, across many disciplines, of how humans have invented throughout our history. This deep historical perspective, coupled with detailed empirical investigations on the nature of invention, has generated a robust narrative about the salient characteristics of the processes underlying human invention. The project brings these insights on the nature of human invention together with assessments by leading AI experts about the type of inventive activity AI can perform now and the type of inventive activity AI could be expected to perform in the foreseeable future. These insights and assessments will inform consideration of whether AI can help mitigate the difficulties encountered by researchers as they search for new knowledge and create new technologies.

The research effort includes: (1) convening a meeting of experts on human invention (drawn from industry and academia in fields such as computer science, engineering, economics, anthropology, psychology, and other disciplines) about the inventive capabilities of AI to assess AI’s current inventive capacities and consider what would constitute signals that AI’s inventive capacities are increasing; (2) developing a deeper understanding of combinatorial invention using patent records to classify the types of inventive novelty generated by the recombination of existing knowledge; (3) assessing which AI capabilities match the different types of combinatorial invention revealed in patents. The research will be reviewed at the end of each year by a subset of the experts who will advise on priorities for research in the subsequent period. The research and insights gathered about how AI invention can offset the decline in human inventive productivity will be summarized in “white papers” to be accessible to the general public online; full versions of the papers will be submitted for publication in peer-reviewed journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project---proposed and initiated before the Covid-19 pandemic and before the bursting into public life of Generative AI (i.e. large language models and ChatGPT) set out to investigate whether the current capabilities of Artificial Intelligence can help humans generate new inventions. The definition of invention is that used by the US Patent Office: new processes, machines, articles of manufacture, compositions of matter, substances and algorithms. The data supporting the investigation consisted of US patent documents and articles published in the scientific literature. The research effort sought to characterize whether development in AI (new AI methods) can contribute to invention. The research effort also involved talking with personnel in the two leading Patent Offices with regards to AI-related methods--the U.S. Patent Office and China's Patent Office---as to whether they assess AI as being capable of augmenting human invention.

The assessment of AI-related invention (meaning, inventions extending AI capabilities) and of developments of AI-related technologies is that these consist primarily of extensions, modifications and refinements of existing capabilities. It does seem unlikely that existing AI capabilities can help invent. It should be noted that both the U.S. and the Chinese patent offices issued guidance, during the project’s duration, stating that AI-assisted inventions are not categorically unpatentable due to improper inventorship if one or more natural persons significantly contributed to the invention. While AI systems cannot be listed as inventors, a natural person using an AI system can still qualify as an inventor if they significantly contributed to the claimed invention. The personnel (economists, examiners and head of technology units) from the US and Chinese patent offices whom the project spoke with expresses the view that AI is not yet at the stage in which it can display inventive capabilities.

If the definition of invention is modified to encompass solving hard search problems---in which finding a solution amounts to searching a large combinatorial space---then the judgement of whether AI can invent is more ambiguous.  AI systems use various problem-solving techniques, including algorithms such as search algorithms, heuristic algorithms, and optimization algorithms, to find the best solution to a given problem. As an example, consider AlphaFold, developed by Google DeepMind, is an AI system that predicts the 3-dimensional structures of proteins with remarkable accuracy. (Proteins are essential molecular machines in our cells, and their 3D shapes determine their functions.) Determining protein structures experimentally is time-consuming and costly. Predicting the functionality of proteins based on their topology was for decades considered a very complex mathematical problem. If finding a solution in a complex search space is akin to inventing, then DeepFold is capable of invention. Much of AI patenting is in the domain of optimization methods. It can be concluded that invention in the realm of AI can be advancing AI’s capabilities for invention.

Publications resulting from the research effort.

Doctoral Dissertation

Wang, J. (2023). Combinatorial Inventions in Artificial Intelligence: Empirical Evidence and Implications for Science, Technology, and Organizations [Ph.D. Dissertation, Arizona State University]. https://www.proquest.com/openview/cd09c5c8d49df820539d6b66786c0927/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=18750&diss=y

Papers submitted to Peer-reviewed Journals

Wang, J., & Lobo, J. (2024). Extensive Growth of Inventions: Evidence from U.S. Patents. Technological Forecasting and Social Change. [Accepted]

Wang, J., Maynard, A., Lobo, J., Michael, K., Motsch, S., & Strumsky, D. (2024). Knowledge Combination Analysis Reveals That Artificial Intelligence Research Is More Like “Normal Science” Than “Revolutionary Science.” Proceedings of the 57th Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences, 5598—5607. https://hdl.handle.net/10125/107058

Conference Presentations

Wang, J. (2022, May 19). Artificial Intelligence is already here. It’s just not evenly distributed. Governance of Emerging Technologies and Science, Phoenix, AZ, USA.

Invited talks

Wang, J. (2024, March). Artificial Intelligence, Science of Science, and Future of Work [Invited Talk]. Center on Technology, Data, and Society, Arizona State University.

Working Papers

Wang, J., Lobo, J., & Strumsky, D. (2024). How Novel is Invention in Artificial Intelligence? Evidence from the U.S. Patenting [Working paper]. [Submitted to Technovation.]

Wang, J., Lobo, J., & Maynard, A. (2024). Combinatorial Exploitation and Exploration (CEE): An Analytical Framework Towards Better Understanding Organizational Invention with Evidence from Patenting in Artificial Intelligence [Working paper] [Submitted to Organization Science.]

In preparation

Wang, J., & Lobo, J., (2024). The Scientific Base of Artificial Intelligence Inventions [In preparation, to be submitted to Science Advances.]

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2024
Modified by: Jose Lobo
